Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Data communication via the vector components of the acoustic field
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project team has developed a cohesive framework for high rate underwater communication via acoustic particle velocity channels. Propagation characteristics of such channels were studied and new communication and signal processing solutions were devised for transceiver design. Given the low data rates offered by the conventional technology and the high demand for fast data and video communication, the team plans to further develop the technology for widespread use. There is a need for improved underwater modems to communicate among underwater sensors, deep-water moored instruments, autonomous underwater vehicles, surface vessels, etc.


Widespread use of this technology has the potential to positively impact offshore oil and gas industry, fishing industry, environmental and ocean monitoring systems to predict natural disasters such as hurricanes, systems for inspection and repair of underwater constructions and facilities, ocean exploration, etc. The developed transformative technology to communicate via particle velocity channels is expected to have a technological impact on underwater communication systems, which have almost exclusively used the acoustic pressure channel for decades. The impact of the proposed plan, if successful, could be the significant advancement of the underwater communication technology in a number of different applications. This could result in a major enhancement of our ability to benefit from the many resources that underlay the world's oceans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over 75% of the earth’s surface is covered with water that overlays many resources upon which our lives depend. High speed wireless underwater data communication using acoustic (sound) waves between underwater sensors, deepwater moored instruments, autonomous underwater vehicles, and surface vessels is of crucial importance in many applications of national interest. Examples include environmental and ocean monitoring to predict natural disasters such as hurricanes, systems for inspection and repair of underwater constructions and facilities, ocean exploration, effective monitoring for offshore oil and gas drilling, military and surveillance applications, and many others. However, the achievable data rates by the conventional underwater communication technologies are much smaller than what is needed for effective communication and management. To have high speed communication links in underwater environments, the transformative concept of communication via the vector components of the acoustic field was originally proposed and developed in our prior NSF supported project.

The main goal of this project was to identify customers who would benefit from the discovery we made on new acoustic communication channels in the prior NSF project, and make a decision on "go" or "no-go" to enter the market.

We sought to understand who the potential customers might be and what specific value propositions we might be able to offer them through the commercialization of our research. We conducted numerous interviews with customers and channel partners and learned about the customer ecosystem. There were three main customer areas we identified: offshore oil and gas field applications, autonomous and unmanned underwater vehicle data links and command and control applications, and real time monitoring and control of underwater sensors and moored underwater instruments. We identified many potential customers and specific value propositions that would benefit from the commercialization of our research. Eventually we made a “go to market” decision.

Commercializing our high speed acoustic communication technology is likely to have a major technological impact on underwater communication systems, which currently rely on low speed modems. Development of our high speed wireless technology will eventually allow the growth of many underwater businesses and systems whose operations have been constrained by very expensive undersea cables or wireless low data rate modems. This will result in a major enhancement in benefiting from the many resources that underlay the world’s oceans.
